A highly efficient copper-incorporated MIL-100(Fe) catalyst (30Cu/MIL-100(Fe)) is reported for sustainable biodiesel production via oleic acid esterification. By systematically tuning copper loading (10–30 %), we demonstrate that 30 % incorporation maximizes catalytic activity while preserving the Metal Organic Frameworks (MOFs) crystalline structure (XRD) and acidic properties (NH₃-TPD). The optimized 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) achieves 88.1 % methyl oleate yield at 60 °C with a 3 wt.% catalyst loading and methanol-to-acid ratio of 47:1, outperforming pristine MIL-100(Fe) by 1.21-fold. Kinetic studies reveal a remarkably low activation energy (19.44 kJ/mol), attributable to the Cu-Fe synergy that facilitates methoxide ion attack on oleic acid-the rate-determining step. Crucially, the catalyst exhibits excellent heterogeneity (no leaching) and reusability (>5 cycles). This work provides a mechanistic blueprint for designing bimetallic MOF catalysts to bridge the gap between biomass valorization and industrial biodiesel production. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords MOF catalysts Biodiesel production Oleic acid esterification Copper-iron synergy Esterification Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The global energy landscape is undergoing a transformative shift as the demand for energy continues to rise alongside the escalating costs and environmental concerns associated with fossil fuels [1,2]. In this context, biodiesel has emerged as a sustainable and renewable alternative to conventional petroleum-based fuels. Derived from vegetable oils or animal fats [3–5], biodiesel offers numerous advantages, including environmental compatibility, higher combustion efficiency, carbon neutrality, and significantly lower sulfur emissions. These attributes make it a compelling candidate for addressing the dual challenges of energy security and environmental sustainability. The production of biodiesel primarily relies on the transesterification of triglycerides or the esterification of long-chain fatty acids with short-chain alcohols, such as methanol or ethanol, in the presence of a catalyst [6,7]. Traditionally, homogeneous base or acid catalysts have been employed for these reactions [8]. However, their use is fraught with limitations, including difficulties in catalyst recovery, generation of substantial wastewater, and challenges in product purification [9,10]. These drawbacks have spurred the exploration of heterogeneous catalysts, which offer distinct advantages such as ease of separation, reusability, non-corrosiveness, and reduced environmental impact [11,12]. Nevertheless, many existing heterogeneous catalysts suffer from issues such as limited surface area, poor accessibility of active sites, and suboptimal performance under mild reaction conditions [4]. In recent years, Metal-Organic Frameworks (MOFs) have garnered significant attention as advanced materials for catalytic applications. MOFs are crystalline, porous structures composed of metal ions coordinated with organic linkers, offering exceptionally high surface areas and tunable porosity [4]. Among these, MIL-100(Fe) has been extensively studied for its versatility in applications ranging from wastewater treatment to biodiesel production [13]. For example, Removal of heavy metals in wastewater treatment, MIL-100(Fe) has been used to adsorb toxic heavy metals like lead (Pb²⁺), cadmium (Cd²⁺), and chromium (Cr⁶⁺) from contaminated water and in transesterification reaction, MIL-100(Fe) has been studied as a heterogeneous catalyst for converting vegetable oils and waste cooking oils into biodiesel [8]. Concurrently, copper-based catalysts have demonstrated excellent redox properties and acid–base bifunctionality, which are valuable in biomass transformation reactions [14]. Recent advances suggest that incorporating copper into MOF frameworks, especially iron-based ones, can produce strong synergistic effects, enhancing catalytic activity beyond the sum of individual components [11]. Additionally, copper has demonstrated remarkable efficiency in organic synthesis due to its ability to facilitate both radical and polar reaction mechanisms through its variable oxidation states. For example, Ullmann Coupling: Copper-catalyzed coupling of aryl halides with nucleophiles like amines or phenols to form C–N and C–O bonds and Selective Hydrogenations: Cu-based catalysts reduce nitroarenes to anilines without affecting other functional groups [15,16]. Despite recent advancements, the development of heterogeneous catalysts that simultaneously exhibit high catalytic activity and exceptionally low activation energies remains a critical challenge in biodiesel production [17,18]. Furthermore, recent studies have highlighted the pressing need for scalable, multifunctional catalytic systems that operate efficiently under mild conditions, with low energy input and high selectivity [19]. Notably, only a limited number of MOF-based catalysts have been reported to achieve activation energies below 30 kJ/mol in esterification reactions—an important benchmark for enabling efficient conversion at reduced temperatures and milder reaction conditions [1]. These considerations underscore the significance of continued research into the design of advanced MOF-derived catalytic materials. This study explores the synergistic effect of copper incorporation into MIL-100(Fe) to enhance catalytic performance in the esterification and transesterification of oleic acid. A series of Cu/MIL-100(Fe) composites with varying copper loadings were synthesized, characterized, and tested under different reaction conditions. Among them, the most effective catalyst was identified for maximizing biodiesel yield. The findings advance MOF-based catalyst development and contribute to greener, more efficient biodiesel production, addressing key energy and environmental challenges. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All chemicals were used directly as received: 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC), Iron (III) Nitrate nonahydrate (Fe(NO3)3 .9H2O), copper(II) chloride dihydrate (CuCl₂·2H₂O), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), Distilled Water, Absolute Ethanol, Methanol (high purity >99 %), Oleic acid (OA, assay > 70 %), alcoholic KOH (0.1 N), Phenol phthalein solution (1 %). 2.2 Synthesis of materials 2.2.1 Synthesis of MIL-100(Fe) via hydrothermal reaction MIL-100(Fe) was synthesized using the hydrothermal reaction method. Fe(NO₃)₃·9H₂O (4.04 g) was dissolved in 15 mL of distilled water in a beaker. Simultaneously, H₃BTC (1.66 g) was dissolved in 15 mL of DMF, followed by the addition of 15 mL of ethanol to ensure complete dissolution. Both solutions were then combined in a 100 mL beaker, which was tightly sealed with plastic wrap and placed on a magnetic stirrer at room temperature for 24 h to allow complete reaction. After stirring, the mixture was filtered using filter paper, and the filtrate was collected in a clean 100 mL beaker. Subsequently, 15 mL of ethanol was heated to 60 °C, and the powder was dispersed in it. The solution was then transferred to a 100 mL centrifuge tube and centrifuged for 15 min. The liquid phase was discarded, and 15 mL of methanol was added to the solid phase, followed by vigorous shaking for 1 min. The sample was then centrifuged again for 15 min, and the washing step was repeated twice (for a total of three washes) to ensure the removal of impurities. After washing, the solid product was transferred to a clean beaker using a glass rod and placed in a moisture oven at 80 °C for 2 h. The beaker was then transferred to a desiccator and allowed to cool for 15 min. The sample was then ground thoroughly using a mortar and pestle. The ground sample was returned to the beaker and placed in a vacuum oven at 80 °C for 12 h to ensure complete drying. Finally, the beaker was removed, and the MOF sample was transferred to a dark bottle, which was tightly sealed for proper storage. 2.2.2 Synthesis of Cu/MIL-100(Fe) The synthesis of Cu/MIL-100(Fe) was carried out using a procedure analogous to that of MIL-100(Fe), with the key modification being the incorporation of varying percentages of CuCl₂·2H₂O relative to the organic linker, H3BTC as presented in Fig. 1 . In this process, a predetermined quantity of CuCl₂·2H₂O was accurately weighed and dissolved in 15 mL of distilled water. This CuCl₂·2H₂O solution was then introduced into the mixture containing Fe(NO3)3 .9H2O and H3BTC, following which the synthesis proceeded identically to the standard MIL-100(Fe) preparation protocol. This approach yielded a series of copper-incorporated MIL-100(Fe) materials, denoted as x-Cu/MIL-100(Fe), where x represents the weight percentage of CuCl₂·2H₂O (10 %, 20 %, and 30 %) relative to H3BTC in the framework. The resulting catalysts were designated as 10Cu/MIL-100(Fe), 20Cu/MIL-100(Fe), and 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe), corresponding to the respective copper loading. 2.3 Characterization The catalysts were characterized using a combination of techniques, including X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area analysis, temperature-programmed desorption (TPD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX), gas chromatography (GC), Atomic absorption Spectroscopy (AAS) and Inductively Coupled Plasma – Optical Emission Spectroscopy ICP-OES, PerkinElmer Optima 8000 instrument at a wavelength of 324.8 nm (specific for Cu). XRD patterns were recorded using a Bruker AXS D8 ADVANCE diffractometer (Germany) to determine the crystalline structure. SEM analysis was conducted with an FEI Inspect 550 microscope, and EDX, coupled with SEM, was employed for elemental composition and mapping. The electronic states of the elements were investigated via XPS using a K-Alpha spectrometer (Thermo Scientific, USA) with monochromatized Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV). The system operated at 3 mA and 12 kV, generating a focused X-ray spot of 400 μm in diameter under ultra-high vacuum conditions (pressure > 1 × 10⁻⁹ Torr, where 1 Torr = 1.333102 Pa). FTIR spectra were obtained using a Nicolet IS10 spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific) to identify functional groups on the catalyst surface. Surface area and porosity were analyzed using the BET method on a 3Flex automatic surface area analyzer. Prior to nitrogen sorption measurements, the samples were degassed at 150 °C. 2.4 Catalytic test The esterification reactions were conducted in 50 mL two-neck glass flasks fitted with condensers to ensure reflux conditions. Each reaction utilized 1 mL of oleic acid and 3 mL of methanol, with 1 % (by weight of fatty acid) of each catalyst added. The reactions were carried out at 60 °C for 2 h under constant stirring. Upon completion, the catalyst was separated via centrifugation, and residual methanol and water were removed by distillation at 100 °C for 1 h. The conversion of OA was determined through titration, employing 0.1 M alcoholic potassium hydroxide (KOH) as the titrant and phenolphthalein as the indicator. The volume of KOH consumed was recorded, and the conversion of OA was calculated using the following equation: (1) Conversion ( % ) = a i − a f a i × 100 % Where ai , and af represent the initial and final concentrations of OA, respectively. Additionally, the methyl oleate product was quantitatively analyzed using gas chromatography (thermos scientific TRACE 1310) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and TR-FAME capillary column (Length 100 m, I.D 0.25 mm, Film 0.20 µm). All experiments were performed in duplicate or triplicate, with results showing high reproducibility and a standard deviation of ±0.02 mass %. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization The XRD patterns of the Cu/MIL-100(Fe) samples with varying copper loading (10–30 wt %) reveal that the characteristic crystalline structure of MIL-100(Fe) is preserved across all samples and fitted with the parent MIL-100(Fe) (Fig. 2 ). The consistent peak positions, particularly around 2θ values of ∼10°, ∼16°, and ∼31°, align well with the known diffraction pattern of MIL-100(Fe) reported in literature, indicating that the framework remains intact after metal incorporation [20,21]. As the Cu content increases, the peak intensities become sharper, suggesting enhanced crystallinity or better dispersion of Cu species within the framework. The absence of additional peaks related to Cu, or its oxide forms implies that the copper is either highly dispersed or incorporated into the framework without forming separate crystalline phases. In the context of Cu/MIL-100(Fe), similar structural behavior is generally expected. Literature reports on Cu incorporation into MIL-100(Fe) suggest that Cu can either be doped into the framework or deposited as CuO nanoparticles [22]. If well-dispersed or doped, the XRD pattern would show preserved MIL-100(Fe) peaks with minor shifts due to Cu’s larger ionic radius. However, at higher Cu loading, new peaks characteristic of CuO (e.g., around 27°, 33°, and 46°) may appear, indicating phase separation. Comparing 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) patterns to both pure MIL-100(Fe) and 10Cu/MIL-100(Fe) can help assess the degree of structural integrity and the form in which Cu is present. The catalytic performance comparison presented in Fig. 3 demonstrates a clear enhancement in the OA conversion during esterification with methanol upon incorporating Cu into the MIL-100(Fe) framework. The parent MIL-100(Fe) catalyst exhibits the lowest conversion (∼71.6 %), indicating moderate intrinsic activity. However, as the Cu content increases from 10 to 30 wt %, catalytic activity progressively improves, with the 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) sample achieving the highest conversion (∼86 %). This improvement can be attributed to the synergistic effect of copper species, which may enhance the number or strength of acid sites or facilitate electron transfer during the reaction. The trend suggests that Cu incorporation into MIL-100(Fe) positively influences catalytic efficiency, with 30 wt % Cu loading providing the most favorable composition under the tested conditions. The BET analysis presented in Fig. 4 reveals a stark contrast in the surface area and porosity characteristics between MIL-100(Fe) and 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe). The N₂ adsorption–desorption isotherm of MIL-100(Fe) (Fig. 4a) exhibits a typical type I and IV hybrid isotherm with a noticeable hysteresis loop, indicating the presence of both microporous and mesoporous structures [23]. In contrast, the 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) sample (Fig. 4b) shows a significantly reduced adsorbed volume, and lacks pronounced hysteresis, suggesting substantial pore blockage or collapse of the porous network. Quantitatively, the BET surface area of pristine MIL-100(Fe) is 1804 m²/g, whereas that of 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) dramatically drops to only 104 m²/g. This sharp decrease indicates that Cu loading has significantly reduced the accessible surface area, likely due to pore filling or structural distortion upon metal incorporation. Although the BET surface area of the Cu-doped MIL-100(Fe) catalyst (30Cu/MIL-100(Fe)) significantly decreased from 1804 m²/g to 104 m²/g, an enhancement in catalytic activity was observed. This indicates that surface area alone is not the dominant factor governing the esterification performance. The improvement can be attributed to the formation of additional Lewis acid sites due to the incorporation of Cu²⁺ ions into the MIL-100(Fe) framework. These new active sites enhance the activation of OA and methanol, thereby increasing the reaction rate. Moreover, the synergistic interaction between Fe and Cu centers likely promotes a more efficient catalytic environment, compensating for the reduced porosity. Therefore, the catalytic performance is mainly influenced by the quality and accessibility of acid sites rather than the total surface area. The pore size distribution curves shown in Fig. 4c further support this observation. MIL-100(Fe) exhibits a broad and uniform pore size distribution centered around ∼3–5 nm, typical of its hierarchical mesoporous framework. However, 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) displays a sharp peak around 8–10 nm, suggesting the development of fewer and larger mesopores, potentially due to framework degradation or aggregation of copper species. The suppression of micropores in the 30Cu sample is evident from the lack of small-pore contributions in the lower (dp/nm) range. Overall, the Cu modification severely affects the textural properties, leading to a dramatic reduction in surface area and a shift in pore structure from microporous/mesoporous to a more irregular mesoporous regime. These structural changes can influence catalytic behavior by altering reactant diffusion and accessibility to active sites. The SEM images in Fig. 5 a and b illustrate the morphological differences between MIL-100(Fe) and 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe), respectively. In Fig. 5a, the pristine MIL-100(Fe) shows a well-defined, agglomerated particle morphology with rough, granular surfaces composed of microcrystalline domains [24]. In contrast, Fig. 5b shows a less uniform morphology for the 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) sample, with larger and flatter particle domains, suggesting partial surface coverage or structural transformation upon Cu incorporation. This morphological change may indicate the deposition of Cu species on the external surfaces or slight framework collapse due to metal interaction. The EDX spectrum in Fig. 5c confirms the presence of Fe and Cu elements, along with Cl, likely from residual synthesis precursors. The sharp peaks corresponding to Fe and Cu validate the successful incorporation of Cu into the MIL-100(Fe) structure. The Cu content determined from EDX is approximately 0.62 wt %, which, although lower than the nominal 30 wt % loading, suggests surface-dispersed Cu or inhomogeneous distribution. The relatively weak Cu signal may also indicate the Cu species are embedded within the structure rather than forming large surface clusters. No unexpected elemental peaks are detected, implying high material purity. Overall, the SEM-EDX analysis supports successful Cu incorporation into MIL-100(Fe) with observable changes in morphology and elemental composition, potentially influencing surface activity and porosity. Fig. 6 displays the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data for MIL-100(Fe) and 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) materials. Fig. 6a presents the survey spectra, revealing the elemental composition of both materials. The presence of peaks corresponding to Fe 2p, O 1 s, and C 1 s are observed in both samples. This indicates the presence of iron, oxygen, and carbon in both MIL-100(Fe) and 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe). The higher intensity of the Fe 2p peak in MIL-100(Fe) compared to 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) in the survey scan suggests a relatively lower concentration of iron in the 30Cu-modified sample, which is expected due to the incorporation of copper. Fig. 6b, c, and d show the high-resolution XPS spectra for Fe 2p, C 1 s, and O 1 s, respectively. In Fig. 6 b, the Fe 2p spectra for both materials are deconvoluted into several peaks. For MIL-100(Fe), peaks at 711.7 eV and 724.82 eV are assigned to Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2, respectively, along with satellite peaks. The 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) sample shows similar Fe 2p peaks at slightly shifted binding energies (711.11 eV and 724.64 eV), also attributed to Fe3+. This suggests that the iron in both materials is primarily in the +3-oxidation state. Fig. 6c shows the C 1 s spectra, with peaks around 284–289 eV corresponding to different carbon environments within the MIL-100 framework. The slight shifts in binding energies and relative intensities of these peaks between the two samples may indicate changes in the chemical environment of carbon atoms upon copper incorporation. Finally, Fig. 6d displays the O 1 s spectra, showing multiple peaks related to different oxygen species. The peaks around 531–535 eV are characteristic of oxygen in various functional groups present in the metal-organic framework. Like the C 1 s spectra, there are subtle differences in the O 1 s spectra between MIL-100(Fe) and 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe), suggesting that the introduction of copper influences the local chemical environment of oxygen atoms. Overall, the XPS data confirms the successful synthesis of both materials and provides insights into the oxidation states of the constituent elements and the impact of copper incorporation on the chemical environment within the MIL-100(Fe) framework. XPS analysis also estimates that the atomic weight percentage of Cu²⁺ in 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) is approximately 0.6 %. While SEM-EDX and XPS are valuable for surface characterization, their semiquantitative nature limits their accuracy in determining the actual bulk composition of materials. To obtain precise quantitative data on copper incorporation into MIL-100(Fe), atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) was employed. AAS revealed Cu contents of 1.628 mg/g, 10.929 mg/g, and 20.332 mg/g for 10Cu/MIL-100(Fe), 20Cu/MIL-100(Fe), and 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe), respectively. These results clearly demonstrate a progressive and consistent increase in copper content with increasing nominal loading, validating the efficiency of the impregnation method. Moreover, the significantly higher accuracy of AAS highlights its essential role in quantitatively assessing metal incorporation, particularly where surface-sensitive techniques like EDX and XPS may underestimate bulk concentrations due to their limited penetration depth. The FTIR spectra in Fig. 7 reveals the key functional groups present in MIL-100(Fe) and 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe), indicating successful framework formation and the influence of Cu incorporation. Both samples exhibit a prominent absorption band above 3000 cm⁻¹, typically attributed to the physiosorbed water or residual solvent trapped within the porous structure. In MIL-100(Fe), a band at 2957 cm⁻¹ is observed, corresponding to C–H stretching vibrations from organic linkers [25]. The 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) sample displays broader and more intense bands in the 1500–700 cm⁻¹ region, suggesting increased framework complexity or metal–ligand interactions induced by Cu addition. Additionally, the shifts and intensity changes in the fingerprint region imply possible coordination of Cu with oxygen atoms from the carboxylate groups, slightly altering the vibrational modes. The retention of major characteristic peaks in both samples confirms that the framework integrity is maintained after Cu incorporation. However, the spectral differences between the two samples also support the idea of Cu interacting with the organic ligands or replacing Fe sites, contributing to modified chemical environments. These spectral features align with structural and morphological observations, supporting successful synthesis and metal incorporation without significant structural degradation. The NH₃-TPD profiles presented in Fig. 8 provide insight into the surface acidity of MIL-100(Fe) and 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe). Both samples exhibit multiple desorption peaks across a wide temperature range, indicating the presence of weak, moderate, and strong acid sites. MIL-100(Fe) displays three main peaks at approximately 250 °C, 360 °C, and 480 °C, corresponding to ammonia desorption from weak, moderate, and strong acid sites, respectively. In contrast, the 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) sample shows not only more intense peaks but also an additional desorption peak around 510 °C, indicating the formation of new, stronger acid sites upon copper incorporation. Quantitatively, the total amount of ammonia adsorbed increases from 1.071 mmol/g for MIL-100(Fe) to 1.387 mmol/g for 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe), confirming that Cu loading enhances the overall acidity of the catalyst. The increased acidity likely arises from the introduction of Lewis acid sites associated with Cu species, which complement the existing Fe-based sites. This enhancement in both the number and strength of acid sites is beneficial for acid-catalyzed reactions such as esterification. The higher desorption temperatures in 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) also suggest stronger interactions between ammonia and surface sites, indicating improved acid strength. Overall, the NH₃-TPD analysis confirms that Cu incorporation significantly boosts the surface acidity of MIL-100(Fe), contributing to its enhanced catalytic performance. 3.2 Catalytic evaluation Based on experimental procedures, 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) was found to be the most effective catalyst among the prepared catalysts. The optimum reaction conditions were studied as follows: 3.2.1 Effect of molar ratio Fig. 9 illustrates the effects of the molar ratio of OA to methanol on the esterification reaction catalyzed by 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe), highlighting the integration of copper into the MIL-100(Fe) framework. The molar ratio significantly influences reaction efficiency, with higher methanol ratios generally enhancing the conversion of OA to methyl oleate by shifting the reaction equilibrium [1]. To determine the optimal conditions, a series of experiments were conducted using OA:MeOH molar ratios ranging from 1:15 to 1:62, under ambient temperature, 1 wt % catalyst loading, and a reaction time of 5 h. The FAME conversion increased progressively with an increasing methanol ratio: 64.9 % at 1:15, 72.86 % at 1:23, 79.84 % at 1:31, 82.2 % at 1:39, reaching a maximum of 85.92 % at 1:47. Further increases in the methanol ratio, specifically 1:55 (86.0 %) and 1:62 (85.8 %), resulted in negligible improvement or a slight decline in conversion. This trend is likely due to thermodynamic equilibrium constraints and the potential dilution of active catalytic sites at excessively high methanol concentrations. These findings confirm that 1:47 is the optimal molar ratio under the studied conditions, offering the best balance between conversion efficiency and methanol utilization. Beyond this point, increasing methanol does not significantly enhance conversion and may lead to unnecessary waste. The 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic activity and maintained high stability and reusability across all tested ratios, underscoring its robustness and suitability for continuous application. Overall, the results highlight the importance of reactant molar ratio optimization in biodiesel production, aiming to maximize yield, minimize methanol consumption, and ensure process cost-effectiveness. The outstanding performance and recyclability of 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) reinforce its potential as an efficient and sustainable catalyst for green biodiesel synthesis. 3.2.2 Effect of reaction temperature Fig. 10 illustrates the effect of temperature on the catalytic esterification of OA with methanol using 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) as a catalyst. The results demonstrate that increasing the reaction temperature significantly enhances the conversion of OA, with the highest yield of 86.96 % achieved at 60 °C under optimized conditions, including a molar ratio of 1:47 (OA to methanol), 1 % catalyst loading, and a reaction time of 5 h. This temperature-dependent improvement is attributed to the enhanced kinetic energy of the reactants, which facilitates more efficient collisions and accelerates the reaction rate. However, temperatures beyond 60 °C may not further increase the yield due to potential limitations such as methanol evaporation or catalyst stability issues [26,27]. Thus, 60 °C is identified as the optimal temperature for maximizing the esterification yield, highlighting the importance of temperature control in achieving efficient biodiesel production. 3.2.3 Effect of catalyst loading Fig. 11 illustrates the effect of catalyst loading on the conversion of OA with methanol using 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) as a catalyst. The results indicate that increasing the catalyst loading initially enhances the yield, peaking at 88.1 % with a 3 % catalyst loading under fixed conditions of a 1:47 molar ratio (OA to methanol), a temperature of 60 °C, and a reaction time of 5 h. This improvement is attributed to the increased availability of active sites, which facilitate more efficient conversion of reactants to products. However, beyond 3 % catalyst loading, the yield slightly decreases, likely due to factors such as mass transfer limitations or potential aggregation of the catalyst particles, which can reduce the effective surface area and accessibility of active sites [28,29]. Therefore, 3 % catalyst loading is identified as the optimal amount for maximizing the esterification yield, emphasizing the importance of balancing catalyst quantity to achieve efficient and cost-effective biodiesel production. 3.2.4 Effect of reaction time Fig. 12 demonstrates the effect of reaction time on the conversion of OA with methanol using 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) as a catalyst. The results reveal that increasing the reaction time significantly improves the yield, with the highest yield of 88.1 % achieved at 5 h under fixed conditions of a 1:47 molar ratio (OA: MeOH), a temperature of 60 °C, and 3 % catalyst loading. This increase in yield over time is attributed to the extended duration allowing for more complete conversion of reactants to products, ensuring that the reaction reaches equilibrium. Beyond 5 h, the yield slightly decreases due to potential side reactions or catalyst deactivation. Therefore, 5 h is identified as the optimal reaction time for maximizing the esterification yield, highlighting the importance of sufficient reaction duration to achieve efficient and high-yield biodiesel production. 3.3 Comparison of catalytic activity and mechanism The data presented in Table 1 clearly demonstrate the superior catalytic performance of 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) in the methanolysis of OA compared to both the parent MIL-100(Fe) and other heterogeneous catalysts reported in the literature. Under mild reaction conditions (60 °C, 5 h, 1:49 OA: MeOH molar ratio, and 3 wt % catalyst loading), 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) achieved an 88 % yield, significantly outperforming MIL-100(Fe), which only reached 71 % under identical conditions. In contrast, catalysts like Al₂O₃, MIL-125(Ti), and HPW@MIL-100 required much harsher conditions (higher temperature, longer time, and greater catalyst loading) yet achieved lower yields ranging from 20 % to 68 %. Even more sophisticated MOF-based systems like PMA/Fe-BTC and S-MOF-808(Zr) needed elevated temperatures (≥130 °C) and much higher catalyst loadings to reach yields of 72 % and 80 %, respectively, which still fall short of 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe). The enhanced catalytic activity of 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) can be attributed to a synergistic mechanism involving both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites. The incorporation of Cu²⁺ into the MIL-100(Fe) framework introduces additional Lewis acid centers that can effectively coordinate and polarize the carbonyl group of oleic acid, making it more susceptible to nucleophilic attack by methanol. Simultaneously, residual Fe³⁺ sites and coordinated hydroxyls may provide Brønsted acidity, facilitating protonation of the carbonyl group and the subsequent formation of the tetrahedral intermediate (Scheme 1 ). The porous architecture of the MOF allows for efficient diffusion of reactants and stabilization of intermediates, while the increased surface acidity (as confirmed by NH₃-TPD) enhances catalytic turnover. This dual acid site mechanism—amplified by the tailored microenvironment within the MOF—enables high catalytic efficiency under mild, green reaction conditions. 3.4 Leaching test The heterogeneity test of the esterification reaction of OA with methanol over 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe), as illustrated in Fig. 13 and supported by the described hot filtration experiment, confirms the truly heterogeneous nature of the catalyst. Initially, a rapid increase in the OA conversion is observed within the first 15 min, reaching approximately 65 %, attributed to the active participation of the 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) catalyst. Once the catalyst was removed from the reaction mixture by hot filtration at this point, the reaction was continued with only the filtration under optimum conditions. The graph clearly shows that no further conversion occurred over the remaining 225 min in the absence of the solid catalyst. This plateau in the conversion profile without catalyst presence, in contrast to the continued increase when the catalyst remains in the system, demonstrates that no active Cu species leached into the solution during the reaction. To verify the stability of the catalyst and the absence of copper leaching during the reaction, the filtrate was analyzed using inductively coupled plasma–optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) at a wavelength of 324.8 nm (specific for Cu). The reaction filtrate was digested using aqua regia (3:1 HCl: HNO₃) to ensure complete dissolution before analysis. The measured copper concentration in the solution was negligible (<1 ppm), indicating that no significant leaching occurred. The analysis was performed in triplicate, yielding consistent and reproducible results. These findings confirm that the catalytic activity of 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) is exclusively attributed to the solid phase, thereby demonstrating the heterogeneous nature of the catalyst under the investigated reaction conditions. Although the catalyst exhibited excellent stability, it is acknowledged that potential leaching under more severe or prolonged reaction conditions cannot be entirely excluded. Further studies will be undertaken to assess long-term catalyst durability and performance. 3.5 Reusability The reusability test of 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) under the optimized reaction conditions demonstrates the catalyst's strong stability and recyclability in the esterification of OA with methanol. As shown in Fig. 14 , the catalyst maintained a high conversion efficiency, starting at 88.1 % in the first cycle (R1) and gradually decreasing to 81.5 % by the fifth cycle (R5). The minor decline in activity over successive runs can be attributed to slight deactivation, possibly due to surface fouling or partial pore blockage. Nevertheless, the consistent OA conversion above 81 % indicates excellent structural integrity and catalytic durability. Between each cycle, the catalyst was carefully recovered, washed, dried, and reactivated at 150 °C for 12 h, ensuring minimal contamination or loss of active sites. These results confirm that 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) functions as a robust and reusable heterogeneous catalyst, capable of sustaining high catalytic performance through multiple reaction cycles with no significant loss of efficiency. 3.6 Kinetic studies are over 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) The esterification kinetics of OA were investigated using a 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) catalyst in a 50 mL batch reactor across a temperature range of 313–353 K. This endothermic reaction demonstrated greater thermodynamic favorability at elevated temperatures. Experimental conditions employed a high OA:MeOH molar ratio (1:47) and a constant catalyst loading of 3 wt. % relative to the acid mass (Fig. 15 ). As expected for such systems, the conversion efficiency showed a positive correlation with increasing temperature [39], consistent with the following reaction scheme: Unlabelled image Overall, the reaction rate (rA ) was estimated based on the following equation: (2) − r A = − ( d C A / d t ) = k C A n (3) C A = C A o ( 1 − X ) Where C A o , X are the initial concentration and conversion of OA, respectively. Thus, the integration of the above equation for concentration CA regarding time t gives rate constant k of nth order as Eq. (4). (4) − ln ( 1 − X ) = k t The activation energy can be evaluated from plotting (lnk) opposite (1/T) as depicted in Arrhenius equation: (5) k = A e ( − E a / R T ) In the Arrhenius equation, Eₐ represents the activation energy, A denotes the frequency factor, R is the universal gas constant (8.314 J/mol·K), and T stands for absolute temperature. Fig. 16 a demonstrates the linear relationship between -ln(1- X) and reaction time at various temperatures, while Fig. 16b presents the corresponding Arrhenius plot of lnk versus 1/T. This plot yields a linear trend where the slope equals -Eₐ/R and the intercept corresponds to lnA. As shown in Table 2 , the rate increases constantly with temperature [40]. The calculated activation energy of 19.44 kJ/mol is significantly lower than literature values (36.73–46.69 kJ/mol) [41,42], clearly demonstrating the catalytic efficacy of 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) in reducing the energy barrier for OA methanolysis. These results indicate that the rate-determining step involves the nucleophilic attack of methoxide ions on OA. 4 Conclusions This study successfully demonstrates the enhanced catalytic performance of copper-incorporated MIL-100(Fe) materials for biodiesel production via OA esterification. Systematic characterization (XRD, BET, NH₃-TPD) confirmed the preservation of MIL-100(Fe)'s crystalline structure upon copper integration, while revealing distinct textural modifications that influenced catalytic activity. The 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) variant emerged as the most effective catalyst, achieving an exceptional methyl oleate yield of 88.1 % under optimized conditions (60 °C, 3 wt. % loading, OA:MeOH ratios of 1:47). The superior performance is attributed to the synergistic interplay between copper and iron sites, which facilitated nucleophilic attack on an OA and lowered the activation energy to 19.44 kJ/mol—a 58 % reduction compared to conventional catalysts. The practical viability of 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) was further underscored by its robust heterogeneity (no detectable Cu leaching) and consistent reusability across multiple cycles. These findings not only advance the design of bimetallic MOF catalysts for sustainable fuel production but also provide mechanistic insights into the role of metal synergy in esterification kinetics. Future work should explore the catalyst’s applicability to diverse feedstocks and scaled-up systems to bridge lab-scale innovation with industrial implementation. coredata.dc:description: A highly efficient copper-incorporated MIL-100(Fe) catalyst (30Cu/MIL-100(Fe)) is reported for sustainable biodiesel production via oleic acid esterification. By systematically tuning copper loading (10–30 %), we demonstrate that 30 % incorporation maximizes catalytic activity while preserving the Metal Organic Frameworks (MOFs) crystalline structure (XRD) and acidic properties (NH₃-TPD). The optimized 30Cu/MIL-100(Fe) achieves 88.1 % methyl oleate yield at 60 °C with a 3 wt.% catalyst loading and methanol-to-acid ratio of 47:1, outperforming pristine MIL-100(Fe) by 1.21-fold. Kinetic studies reveal a remarkably low activation energy (19.44 kJ/mol), attributable to the Cu-Fe synergy that facilitates methoxide ion attack on oleic acid-the rate-determining step. Crucially, the catalyst exhibits excellent heterogeneity (no leaching) and reusability (>5 cycles). This work provides a mechanistic blueprint for designing bimetallic MOF catalysts to bridge the gap between biomass valorization and industrial biodiesel production.
